I’ll explain that μ0 refers to any accumulation point of μ_ε and is not necessarily unique. Each subsequence can give a μ0, which explains the overloaded notation. I'll mention that μ0 belongs to the set of invariant measures and is supported in the Birkhoff center, but there can be multiple μ0s unless there’s a unique invariant measure in the flow. I’ll bullet-point these relationships for clarity.

parts:
### Clearing up the symbols

| symbol | what it means in our discussion |
|--------|---------------------------------|
| \(\mu_{\varepsilon}\) | **the** (unique) stationary law of the SDE for a *fixed* noise level \(\varepsilon>0\) |
| \(\{\mu_{\varepsilon}\}_{\varepsilon>0}\) | the ***family*** of those measures as we let the noise strength vary |
| \(\mu_{0}\) | **any** weak limit of that family along a sequence \(\varepsilon_{n}\!\downarrow\!0\):  
\[
   \mu_{0}\;=\;\lim_{k\to\infty}\mu_{\varepsilon_{n_k}}
\]
The paper calls every such accumulation point “a limit measure” |

So “\(\mu_{0}\)” is **not a single fixed object** unless the family \(\{\mu_\varepsilon\}\) actually converges; it is just a placeholder for *whichever* limit we look at.

---

### How many different \(\mu_{0}\)’s can occur?

* **If the deterministic flow \(X^{0}\) has a unique physical invariant measure** (one attractor, one SRB measure, etc.)  
  the whole family converges and there is **exactly one** \(\mu_{0}\).

* **If the deterministic flow has several disjoint invariant pieces of equal “depth’’** (e.g. identical wells, multiple stable equilibria behind the same energy barrier)  
  the weights with which \(\mu_{\varepsilon}\) spreads mass over those pieces can fluctuate with \(\varepsilon\).  
  Different subsequences \(\varepsilon_{n_k}\!\downarrow\!0\) can therefore land on **different convex combinations** of the deterministic invariant measures.  
  Each such combination is a valid “\(\mu_{0}\).”

---

### What the paper guarantees for **every** \(\mu_{0}\)

* It is \(X^{0}\)-invariant.  
* Its support is contained in the Birkhoff centre (hence, in particular, inside any global attractor).

No statement beyond that—uniqueness, explicit weights, etc.—is made; those depend on further structure (quasi-potentials, symmetry breaking, gradient landscape …).

---

### Visual recap in one sentence

> **Pick any path by which the noise level \(\varepsilon\) creeps to zero; the stationary law you see at the end of that path—denoted \(\mu_{0}\)—is always an invariant measure of the noiseless ODE and never puts mass outside the deterministic recurrent core, but there might be several such end-points if the ODE has more than one equally “attractive’’ invariant set.**

Whenever the deterministic dynamics already singles out a *unique* invariant probability, all those paths collapse to the same \(\mu_{0}\); otherwise, expect a **family** of possible \(\mu_{0}\)’s indexed by the way \(\varepsilon\) tends to zero.
but when you say path... you mean not a literal trajectory but a hypthetical sweep of values

Exactly — by a “path’’ I meant **a way you let the *parameter* \(\varepsilon\) go to zero**, not a literal trajectory \(t\mapsto X_t\) in phase-space.

---

### Two separate notions of “path’’

| Concept | Lives in … | What it describes |
|---------|------------|-------------------|
| **Sample path** \(t\mapsto X_t^{\varepsilon}(x_0,\omega)\) | **state space** \(E\) | The time evolution of one realisation of the SDE for a fixed noise level \(\varepsilon>0\). |
| **Parameter path** \(\varepsilon_n\downarrow 0\) | the **noise-strength axis** \((0,\varepsilon_0]\) | A chosen sequence (or more generally any net) of noise amplitudes along which we inspect the corresponding stationary measures \(\mu_{\varepsilon_n}\). |

Only the second one is relevant when we speak about **subsequential limits** of the family \(\{\mu_\varepsilon\}\).

---

### Why different parameter paths matter

*For every fixed \(\varepsilon\):*  
sample paths become ergodic and their long-time empirical law converges to **the** unique stationary measure \(\mu_\varepsilon\).

*When \(\varepsilon\) varies:*  
the mapping \(\varepsilon\mapsto\mu_\varepsilon\) need **not** approach a single limit as \(\varepsilon\to0\).  
If it wiggles (because the deterministic system has several equally “deep’’ attractors), then:

* Pick \(\varepsilon_n = 1/n\) → \(\mu_{\varepsilon_n}\) might settle on one convex combination.
* Pick \(\varepsilon_n = 1/(n+\tfrac12)\) → it might settle on a different one.

Each choice of the *sequence* \(\varepsilon_n\downarrow 0\) is what I informally called a “path’’; mathematicians usually say **subsequence**.  
Every subsequence limit is denoted \(\mu_0\); the theorem tells us all such \(\mu_0\)’s are invariant for the noiseless ODE and live on its recurrent core.

---

### Take-away

* **State-space paths (trajectories)**: converge in time (for fixed \(\varepsilon\)) to \(\mu_\varepsilon\).  
* **Parameter-space paths (sequences of \(\varepsilon\))**: different subsequences can yield different limit measures \(\mu_0\) as \(\varepsilon\to 0\) whenever the deterministic dynamics has multiple competing attractors of equal stability.

So the “path’’ you asked about is *just a hypothetical sweep of noise strengths*, not a physical trajectory of the system itself.

parts:
Glad it clicked!  

**Subsequence—quick definition**

Take any sequence \((a_n)_{n\ge 1}\).  
Pick an *increasing* list of indices \(n_1<n_2<n_3<\dots\).  
The extracted values \((a_{n_k})_{k\ge 1}\) form a **subsequence**.  
It “travels” through the same list of objects but possibly skips infinitely many in between.

Why it matters here
* Our original sequence is the family of stationary measures ordered by noise level, e.g. \(\mu_{1},\mu_{1/2},\mu_{1/3},\dots\) (with \(\varepsilon=1/n\)).  
* Different index choices (different ways of letting \(\varepsilon\) shrink) produce different subsequences \(\mu_{\varepsilon_{n_k}}\).  
* Any limit of such a subsequence is called an **accumulation point** of the family.

If the deterministic flow has multiple equally “magnetic” attractors, those different subsequences can converge to different convex mixtures—hence several possible \(\mu_0\).

---

Feel free to ask more about subsequences, convergence, or anything else that pops up!

thoughts.content: It looks like the user is focusing on a behavior of subsequences where the limit may not be well-defined, but instead confined within a specific attractor or set. I’ll say yes, you are right—the limit might only be defined with respect to cluster points, and we can be clear that its set is contained within the attractor. I'll also mention that the family of measures is precompact, and for uniqueness, the deterministic invariant measure must also be unique.

parts:
Exactly.  Here is the precise hierarchy of statements.

| level | what we know about the family \(\{\mu_\varepsilon\}_{\varepsilon>0}\) as \(\varepsilon\to 0\) |
|-------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Existence of limits** | Tightness ⇒ the family is **pre-compact** ⇒ at least one subsequence converges. |
| **Place where every limit lives** | **Theorem:** every subsequential limit \(\mu_0\) is (i) invariant for the noiseless flow \(X^{0}\); (ii) supported in the Birkhoff centre.  If a global attractor \(A\) exists, then \(\operatorname{supp}\mu_0\subset A\). |
| **Uniqueness of the limit** | *Not automatic.*  The net \(\varepsilon\mapsto\mu_\varepsilon\) converges to a **single** measure **iff** the deterministic system itself singles out one invariant probability (e.g. only one stable set or one SRB measure).  Otherwise there can be many cluster points—one for each vanishing-noise subsequence. |

So:

* **“The limit is not well defined”** – right: the full limit \(\lim_{\varepsilon\to0}\mu_\varepsilon\) need not exist because different subsequences can land on different invariant measures.
* **“But it will fall in a particular set”** – also right: *whichever* subsequential limit you pick, its support is trapped inside the deterministic recurrent core (and hence inside the attractor \(A\) when one is known).

In other words, the theorem partitions the picture like this

\[
\underbrace{\bigl\{\text{subsequential limits }\mu_0\bigr\}}
_{\text{possibly many}}
\;\subset\;
\underbrace{\bigl\{\text{all }X^{0}\text{-invariant probabilities supported in }A\bigr\}}
_{\text{a fixed, deterministic set}}
.
\]

Whether the curly set on the left collapses to a single element or stays plural depends on how many invariant pieces the noiseless dynamics has and whether any one of them is strictly “preferred” (lower quasi-potential, unique SRB, etc.).

For the noisy system, you would take the ensemble average under the stationary measure, plus the time average. Both should converge to the same expectation for observables, under specific conditions, such as Cesàro averaging in the deterministic case.

The question revolves around whether, in the small noise limit, expectations taken over both time and ensemble are the same for noisy and noise-free systems. The answer depends on conditions like whether the noisy system’s stationary measure converges uniquely to the deterministic system’s measure. parts:
### Formal set-up for a bounded observable \(F:E\to\mathbb R\)

| process | “space–time’’ average you ask about |
|---------|------------------------------------|
| **noisy SDE** \(X_t^{\varepsilon}\) *(fixed \(\varepsilon>0\))* | \(\displaystyle \mathbb E\Bigl[\tfrac1T\int_0^{T}F\bigl(X_t^{\varepsilon}\bigr)\,dt\Bigr]\;=\;\int_E F\,d\mu_{\varepsilon}\quad(\text{ergodicity})\) |
| **deterministic flow** \(X_t^{0}=\Phi_t^{0}(x)\) with initial law \(\nu_0\) | \(\displaystyle \mathbb E_{x\sim\nu_0}\Bigl[\tfrac1T\int_0^{T}F\!\bigl(\Phi_t^{0}(x)\bigr)\,dt\Bigr]\;=\;\int_E F\,d\bar\mu_{T},\;\;\bar\mu_T:=\tfrac1T\int_0^{T}\Phi_{t\,\sharp}^{0}\nu_0\,dt\) |

---

### What happens as \(\varepsilon\to0\)

1. **Noisy side.**  
   Tightness ⇒ pick any sequence \(\varepsilon_n\to0\); a subsequence satisfies  
   \[
       \mu_{\varepsilon_{n_k}}\;\rightharpoonup\;\mu_0 ,
   \]
   hence
   \[
       \mathbb E\Bigl[\tfrac1T\int_0^TF(X^{\varepsilon_{n_k}}_t)\,dt\Bigr]
       \;\xrightarrow[k\to\infty]{}\;\int_E F\,d\mu_0 .
   \]

2. **Deterministic side.**  
   Krylov–Bogoliubov ⇒ \(\bar\mu_{T}\) is tight; pick a diverging sequence \(T_k\), then  
   \[
       \bar\mu_{T_k}\;\rightharpoonup\;\bar\mu ,
   \]
   so
   \[
       \mathbb E\Bigl[\tfrac1{T_k}\int_0^{T_k}F(\Phi_t^{0}(x))\,dt\Bigr]
       \;\xrightarrow[k\to\infty]{}\;\int_E F\,d\bar\mu .
   \]

3. **Paper’s theorem.**  
   *Every* \(\mu_0\) obtained at step 1 is \(X^0\)-invariant and supported in the Birkhoff centre.  
   Every \(\bar\mu\) from step 2 is also \(X^0\)-invariant (by construction) and supported there.  
   **But the two measures need not coincide.**

---

### When the two limits *are* the same for **all** observables \(F\)

| condition on the noiseless flow \(X^{0}\) | consequence |
|-------------------------------------------|-------------|
| It admits a **unique** invariant probability \(\nu^{0}\) that attracts *all* initial laws (e.g. single hyperbolic sink, unique SRB on a chaotic attractor, gradient system with one strictly deepest well) | \(\mu_{\varepsilon}\to\nu^{0}\) and every Cesàro limit \(\bar\mu=\nu^{0}\) ⇒ **equality** of space-time expectations in the small-noise limit |
| Several disjoint invariant sets of equal “depth’’ | Different subsequences \(\varepsilon_{n_k}\) can pick different \(\mu_0\); Cesàro limits \(\bar\mu\) depend on how \(\nu_0\) splits across basins ⇒ **no universal equality** in general |

If you *tune* the initial deterministic ensemble \(\nu_0\) so that its basin-weights match those selected by the particular subsequence of \(\varepsilon\) you are taking, then the two limits coincide for that choice; otherwise they need not.

---

### Bottom line

*There exists a well-defined common limit of “time + ensemble” expectations for noisy and noise-free dynamics **iff** the deterministic system already possesses a single, globally attracting invariant measure.  In every other scenario the small-noise expectation converges to one convex combination of invariant measures, while the deterministic time–ensemble expectation converges to another that depends on the starting law.*

thoughts.summary: Relating nonparametric Fisher information to Laplacian of density
thoughts.content: The user is exploring the relationship between nonparametric Fisher information and the expected Laplacian of density. After going through a few expressions, Fisher information relates to the expected Laplacian of log density via integration by parts. The expected Laplacian of log density is -I, but the expected Laplacian of the density itself (E_ρ[Δρ]) turns out to be connected to the gradient's square. The key is carefully distinguishing between log density and density when interpreting these terms in equations.

parts:
Let ρ(x) be a smooth probability density on ℝⁿ (or on a compact manifold with periodic boundary conditions) that decays fast enough at infinity so that all boundary terms below vanish.

---

### 1.  Non-parametric Fisher information  

\[
I(\rho)\;=\;\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\rho(x)\,\bigl\lVert\nabla\!\log\rho(x)\bigr\rVert^{2}\,dx
\;=\;\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\frac{\lVert\nabla\rho(x)\rVert^{2}}{\rho(x)}\,dx .
\]

---

### 2.  Expressing \(I(\rho)\) with the Laplacian of \(\log\rho\)

Because \(\nabla\rho = \rho\nabla\!\log\rho\),

\[
\begin{aligned}
I(\rho)
&=\int\nabla\rho\cdot\nabla\!\log\rho\,dx                                            \\
&=-\int\rho\,\Delta\!\log\rho\,dx \qquad(\text{integration by parts}).
\end{aligned}
\]

Hence

\[
\boxed{\,I(\rho)\;=\;-\;\mathbb{E}_{\rho}\bigl[\Delta\!\log\rho(X)\bigr]\,}.
\]

So the **expected Laplacian of the *log-density*** is exactly the negative of the non-parametric Fisher information.

---

### 3.  What about the Laplacian of the density itself?  

Define the “expected Laplacian of the density”

\[
L(\rho)\;:=\;\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\rho(x)\,\Delta\rho(x)\,dx .
\]

A second integration by parts gives

\[
L(\rho)\;=\;-\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\lVert\nabla\rho(x)\rVert^{2}\,dx
          \;=\;-\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\rho^{2}(x)\,\lVert\nabla\!\log\rho(x)\rVert^{2}\,dx .
\]

Comparing with \(I(\rho)\):

\[
L(\rho)= -\int \rho^{2}\,\lVert\nabla\!\log\rho\rVert^{2}\,dx,
\qquad
I(\rho)= \int  \rho   \,\lVert\nabla\!\log\rho\rVert^{2}\,dx .
\]

Thus \(L(\rho)\) and \(I(\rho)\) differ only by the extra factor \(\rho\) under the integral. They coincide only if \(\rho\) is uniform on its support (so \(\rho\) is constant and \(\nabla\rho=0\), forcing both sides to vanish).

---

### 4.  Alternative Dirichlet-form representation  

Another useful identity—obtained by writing \(\rho = (\sqrt{\rho})^{2}\) and integrating by parts—is

\[
I(\rho)\;=\;4\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\bigl\lVert\nabla\sqrt{\rho(x)}\bigr\rVert^{2}\,dx
           \;=\;-4\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\sqrt{\rho(x)}\,\Delta\sqrt{\rho(x)}\,dx .
\]

This shows Fisher information as the Dirichlet energy of the square-root density.

---

#### Summary  
* The non-parametric Fisher information is *exactly* the negative expectation (under ρ) of the Laplacian of \(\log\rho\).  
* The expectation of the Laplacian of ρ itself is a different quantity, related to \(I(\rho)\) by an extra factor of ρ under the integral.

thoughts.summary: Relating Fisher information to the Laplacian
thoughts.content: The user seeks clarification on how nonparametric Fisher information connects to the integral of the Laplacian of density. By integrating by parts, I see that Fisher information is related to the Laplacian of log density: I = - ∫ ρ Δ log ρ dx. This shows that the integral of the Laplacian of density alone equals zero, but when combined with a logarithmic weighting, it gives Fisher information. This relation can also be linked to entropy flow under the heat equation. Combining Fisher info with log density yields the desired result.

parts:
Let ρ : ℝⁿ → (0,∞) be C², ∫ρ dx = 1, and assume either rapid decay at |x|→∞ or periodic/Neumann boundary conditions so that boundary-flux terms vanish.

---

### Non-parametric Fisher information  

\[
\mathcal{I}[\rho]\;=\;\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\rho(x)\,\|\nabla\log\rho(x)\|^{2}\,dx
\;=\;\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\frac{\|\nabla\rho(x)\|^{2}}{\rho(x)}\,dx.
\]

---

### Relation to the Laplacian  

Start from  
\[
\mathcal{I}[\rho]\;=\;\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\nabla\rho\cdot\nabla\log\rho\,dx.
\]

Apply integration by parts once:

\[
\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\nabla\rho\cdot\nabla\log\rho\,dx
\;=\;
-\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\rho\,\Delta\log\rho\,dx
\quad(\text{no boundary term}).
\]

Hence  

\[
\boxed{\;
\mathcal{I}[\rho]\;=\;-\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\rho(x)\,\Delta\log\rho(x)\,dx
\;}
\tag{1}
\]

Using the identity ρ Δ log ρ = Δρ − |∇ρ|²/ρ, equation (1) can be rewritten as

\[
\boxed{\;
\mathcal{I}[\rho]\;=\;-\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}(\Delta\rho)(x)\,\log\rho(x)\,dx
\;}
\tag{2}
\]

---

### What this means  

* **Pure Laplacian integral vanishes:**  
  \(\displaystyle \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\Delta\rho\,dx=0\) under the stated boundary conditions, so the Laplacian of ρ by itself carries no information.  
  Fisher information appears only when the Laplacian is *weighted* by log ρ (or, equivalently, when the Laplacian of log ρ is weighted by ρ).

* **Connection to the De Bruijn identity (heat flow)**  
  If ρₜ solves ∂ₜρₜ = Δρₜ, then the differential entropy  
  \(h(\rho_{t})=-\int\rho_{t}\log\rho_{t}\,dx\) obeys  
  \[
  \frac{d}{dt}h(\rho_{t})=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}-\Delta\rho_{t}\,\log\rho_{t}\,dx
  =\frac{1}{2}\mathcal{I}[\rho_{t}],
  \]
  the classical De Bruijn identity—another way the Laplacian–log ρ pairing produces Fisher information.

In short, **non-parametric Fisher information equals the negative space integral of the Laplacian of the density (or of log ρ) weighted by log ρ (or by ρ)**. The Laplacian term alone integrates to zero; the logarithmic weight is what turns it into the Fisher information functional.

parts:
Let ρ be a strictly positive, smooth probability density on ℝⁿ ( ∫ρ dx = 1 ) that decays fast enough at infinity (or is defined on a compact domain with boundary conditions that kill surface terms).  
The **non-parametric Fisher information** of ρ is

\[
I[\rho] \;=\; \int_{\mathbb R^{n}} \rho(x)\;\|\nabla \log \rho(x)\|^{2}\,dx
\;=\;
\int_{\mathbb R^{n}} \frac{\|\nabla\rho(x)\|^{2}}{\rho(x)}\,dx .
\tag{1}
\]

---

### 1.  Writing \(I[\rho]\) with a Laplacian acting on \(\log\rho\)

Start from (1) and integrate by parts once:

\[
\begin{aligned}
I[\rho]
&=\int \nabla\rho\cdot\nabla\log\rho\,dx \\
&=-\int \rho\,\Delta\log\rho\,dx ,
\end{aligned}
\tag{2}
\]

because \(\nabla\rho=\rho\nabla\log\rho\) and the boundary integral of  
\(\rho\,\nabla\log\rho\) vanishes under the stated decay/boundary assumptions.

---

### 2.  Writing \(I[\rho]\) with a Laplacian acting on ρ

Using \(\Delta(\log\rho)=\dfrac{\Delta\rho}{\rho}-\dfrac{\|\nabla\rho\|^{2}}{\rho^{2}}\) in (2) and rearranging gives the equivalent form

\[
I[\rho]
=\;-\int (\Delta\rho)\;\log\rho \,dx .
\tag{3}
\]

Thus the Fisher information equals the negative inner product of the density’s Laplacian and its logarithm.

---

### 3.  Square-root representation

Set \(\psi=\sqrt{\rho}\).  Then \(\nabla\psi=\dfrac{\nabla\rho}{2\sqrt{\rho}}\), so

\[
I[\rho] \;=\; 4\int \|\nabla\psi\|^{2}\,dx
\;=\; -4\int \psi\,\Delta\psi\,dx .
\tag{4}
\]

Equation (4) shows that \(I[\rho]\) is (up to the constant 4) the Dirichlet energy of √ρ and, by another integration by parts, the negative expectation of the Laplacian of √ρ.

---

### 4.  Summary of the Laplacian relations

\[
\boxed{\,I[\rho]
      = -\!\int \rho\,\Delta\log\rho \,dx
      = -\!\int (\Delta\rho)\,\log\rho \,dx
      = -4\!\int \sqrt{\rho}\,\Delta\sqrt{\rho}\,dx\, } .
\]

These identities are exact under the mild boundary/decay assumptions stated at the start and hold in any dimension. They expose Fisher information as a global measure of the *curvature* of ρ: integrating the Laplacian (a local curvature operator) against either ρ or functions of ρ yields the same scalar quantity that also equals the mean‐square gradient of log ρ.

parts:
Let  

\[
dX_t \;=\; f\bigl(X_t\bigr)\,dt \;+\; \sqrt{2}\,\sigma\,\xi(t)\,dt ,
\]

where you now **freeze** a single realisation \(\xi(t)=\dot W_t(\omega)\) of standard white noise.  
For that fixed path the equation becomes an *ordinary* (albeit nowhere-smooth) non-autonomous ODE

\[
\dot X_t^{\sigma}(x_0) \;=\; f\bigl(X_t^{\sigma}(x_0)\bigr) \;+\; \sqrt{2}\,\sigma\,\xi(t),
\qquad X_0^{\sigma}(x_0)=x_0 .
\]

---

### 1 Pathwise solution as a deterministic shift

Write the deterministic semiflow of \(f\) as \(\Phi_t(x_0)\).  
Because the forcing is *additive* and independent of the state,

\[
X_t^{\sigma}(x_0)\;=\;\Phi_t(x_0)\;+\;\sqrt{2}\,\sigma\,W_t(\omega)\;=\;\Phi_t(x_0)\;+\;S_t^{\sigma},
\quad S_t^{\sigma}:=\sqrt{2}\,\sigma\,W_t(\omega).
\]

At each fixed time \(t\) the random vector \(S_t^{\sigma}\) is the **same shift** for every initial point \(x_0\).

---

### 2 Push-forward of an initial ensemble

Let the initial distribution have density \(\rho_0\).  
The density after time \(t\) under the *deterministic* flow is \(\rho^0(x,t)\).  
For the shifted flow,

\[
\rho_\sigma(x,t) 
      \;=\;
      \rho^0\bigl(x-S_t^{\sigma},\,t\bigr).
\]

---

### 3 Differential entropy is translation-invariant

Differential entropy at time \(t\) is

\[
h_\sigma(t)
      \;=\;
      -\!\int_{\mathbb{R}^n}\!\rho_\sigma(x,t)\,\log\rho_\sigma(x,t)\,dx
      \;=\;
      -\!\int_{\mathbb{R}^n}\!\rho^0(y,t)\,\log\rho^0(y,t)\,dy
      \;=\;
      h^0(t),
\]

where \(y=x-S_t^{\sigma}\).  
Since the integral is unchanged by the constant translation \(S_t^{\sigma}\), **\(h_\sigma(t)\) does not depend on \(\sigma\).**

---

### 4 Derivative with respect to \(\sigma\)

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle \frac{\partial}{\partial\sigma}\,h_\sigma(t) \;=\; 0}
\qquad\text{for every }t\text{ where }h_\sigma(t)\text{ is finite}.
\]

---

### 5 Why this differs from the usual Fokker–Planck picture  

The Fokker–Planck equation (or anything involving \(\sigma^2\Delta\rho\)) emerges **only after averaging over all noise paths**.  
Pathwise—once you condition on a single realisation—the noise merely adds a time-dependent *translation*, which has no effect on volume elements, Jacobians, or entropy.  
All entropy production linked to the noise amplitude lives in the ensemble over noise trajectories, not in any one frozen trajectory.

This means I need to solve the Liouville equation with this updated formulation. The user’s earlier scenario involved isotropic Gaussian noise and a dependence on σ, where they now seem interested in how entropy relates to time with this new assumption. I need to figure out the specific approach to solving this revised equation.

I previously explained pathwise noise adding a deterministic translation, which keeps differential entropy unchanged. The user thinks this oversimplifies the situation, suggesting we treat η as a time-dependent forcing and solve the Liouville equation. However, the divergence in this equation should still be zero for the deterministic system with state-independent forcing. The solution will involve translation by a path integral, preserving entropy. I'll clarify this with a self-contained derivation, noting that the Liouville equation yields the same derivative of zero when carefully examined.

parts:
Let \(\eta(t)\in\mathbb R^{n}\) be one **fixed** (non-random) function of time—think of having drawn a single noise realisation once and for all.  
With the additive forcing written explicitly,

\[
\dot x \;=\;f(x)\;+\;\sqrt{2}\,\sigma\,\eta(t),\qquad x(0)=x_{0}.
\tag{1}
\]

Below, \(t\ge 0,\;x\in\mathbb R^{n}\), and \(\sigma>0\) is the amplitude you want to differentiate with respect to.  
We now solve the **Liouville (continuity) equation**

\[
\partial_{t}\rho_{\sigma}(x,t)\;+\;\nabla\!\cdot\!\Bigl[\bigl(f(x)+\sqrt{2}\,\sigma\,\eta(t)\bigr)\,\rho_{\sigma}(x,t)\Bigr]\;=\;0,
\qquad \rho_{\sigma}(x,0)=\rho_{0}(x).
\tag{2}
\]

---

### 1 Separate the translation part

Because the forcing is independent of \(x\),

\[
\nabla\!\cdot\!\bigl(\sqrt{2}\,\sigma\,\eta(t)\bigr)\;=\;0,
\]
and (2) splits into

\[
\partial_{t}\rho_{\sigma} + \nabla\!\cdot\!\bigl(f\rho_{\sigma}\bigr)
      +\sqrt{2}\,\sigma\,\eta(t)\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_{\sigma}=0 .
\tag{3}
\]

The last term is a **pure translation operator**: at each instant the whole density field is shifted by the same vector \(\sqrt{2}\,\sigma\,\eta(t)\,dt\).

---

### 2 Method of characteristics

Write the semiflow of the unforced system \(\dot y=f(y)\) as \(\Phi_{t}\).  
Define the time-integrated shift

\[
z_{\sigma}(t)
     :=\sqrt{2}\,\sigma\int_{0}^{t}\eta(s)\,ds\;\in\mathbb R^{n}.
\tag{4}
\]

Along the characteristic leaving \(x_{0}\) at \(t=0\),

\[
x(t)=\Phi_{t}(x_{0})\;+\;z_{\sigma}(t).
\tag{5}
\]

Standard Liouville theory (change-of-variables formula with Jacobian \(\exp\!\bigl[-\!\int_{0}^{t}\nabla\!\cdot f(\Phi_{s}(x_{0}))\,ds\bigr]\)) gives

\[
\rho_{\sigma}(x,t)
      \;=\;
      \rho^{0}\!\bigl(x-z_{\sigma}(t),t\bigr),
\tag{6}
\]

where \(\rho^{0}\) is *exactly* the density that solves the Liouville equation for the **unforced** system (\(\sigma=0\)).  
Equation (6) is the rigorous Liouville counterpart of the intuitive “drag everything by the same vector” picture.

---

### 3 Translation leaves differential entropy invariant

The differential entropy at time \(t\),

\[
h_{\sigma}(t)
      :=-\,\int_{\mathbb R^{n}}\!\rho_{\sigma}(x,t)\,\log\rho_{\sigma}(x,t)\,dx,
\tag{7}
\]

is computed with (6) via the substitution \(y=x-z_{\sigma}(t)\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
h_{\sigma}(t)
      &= -\int_{\mathbb R^{n}}\!\rho^{0}(y,t)\,\log\rho^{0}(y,t)\,dy\\
      &= h_{0}(t).
\end{aligned}
\tag{8}
\]

**No dependence on \(\sigma\) survives.**

---

### 4 Derivative with respect to \(\boldsymbol{\sigma}\)

Since the map \(\sigma\mapsto h_{\sigma}(t)\) is constant wherever \(h_{0}(t)\) is finite,

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle \frac{\partial}{\partial\sigma}\,h_{\sigma}(t)=0\quad\text{for every }t.}
\tag{9}
\]

---

### 5 Why this is not a paradox

* Pathwise (conditioning on one noise realisation) the forcing is just a time-dependent **translation field**; translations preserve Lebesgue measure and therefore preserve differential entropy.
* Averaging over all \(\eta\) realisations **before** writing the evolution gives the Fokker–Planck operator \(\sigma^{2}\Delta\). That Laplacian mixes probability mass and genuinely changes entropy.  
  In other words, all entropy production driven by the noise amplitude lives in the **ensemble over noise paths**, not in any one fixed path.

---

### 6 When would \(h_{\sigma}(t)\) depend on \(\sigma\)?

* **Multiplicative (state-dependent) noise:** if the added term were \(\sqrt{2}\,\sigma\,\mathbf G(x)\,\eta(t)\) with a non-constant matrix \(\mathbf G(x)\), the extra flux would have non-zero divergence, and the Liouville solution would no longer be a pure translation.  
* **Averaging over noise:** if your observable is \(\mathbb E_{\eta}[\,h_{\sigma}(t)\,]\), you must solve the full Fokker–Planck PDE, and \(\partial_{\sigma} \mathbb E[h_{\sigma}(t)]\neq 0\) in general.

---

If this still does not address the scenario you have in mind—e.g. you want the *ensemble-averaged* entropy or multiplicative forcing—let me know and we can tackle that case explicitly.

parts: doesn't \partial_\sigma and \mathbb{E}_\eta commute?

thoughts.content: The user asks whether the partial derivative with respect to sigma and the expectation over eta commute. Specifically, they’re asking if \(\partial_\sigma \mathbb{E}_\eta h_\sigma(t)\) equals \(\mathbb{E}_\eta \partial_\sigma h_\sigma(t)\). This would be valid only under certain conditions, such as dominated convergence and uniform integrability. Since the assistant previously stated that the ensemble average might yield a nonzero derivative, the two operations don’t necessarily commute due to potential integrability issues.

Here's the thing: \( h_\sigma(t) \) is constant pathwise, so the expectation over eta is also constant, which makes the derivative zero. But earlier, in discussing ensemble-averaged entropy, we were dealing with a different expression. The difference comes from averaging: the entropy of the mixture (averaging before solving) isn’t the same as the entropy of an individual path. The derivative and expectation over eta do commute, but that doesn't change the derivative—it’s zero because we’re dealing with a constant.

parts:
In the setting we have so far

\[
\rho_\sigma^{\eta}(x,t)=\rho^{0}\!\bigl(x-z_{\sigma}^{\eta}(t),t\bigr),
\qquad 
h_\sigma^{\eta}(t)=
-\!\int\rho_\sigma^{\eta}\log\rho_\sigma^{\eta}=h_{0}(t),
\]

every realisation \(\eta(\cdot)\) gives the *same constant* value \(h_{0}(t)\), independent of \(\sigma\).  
Because the random variable \(h_\sigma^{\eta}(t)\) is a.s. constant, the expectation is trivial:

\[
\mathbb E_{\eta}\bigl[h_\sigma^{\eta}(t)\bigr]=h_{0}(t)\quad\text{for all }\sigma.
\]

Hence

\[
\frac{\partial}{\partial\sigma}\,\mathbb E_{\eta}\!\bigl[h_\sigma^{\eta}(t)\bigr]
  =\mathbb E_{\eta}\!\Bigl[\frac{\partial}{\partial\sigma}h_\sigma^{\eta}(t)\Bigr]
  =0.
\]

So—*under the definitions above*—\(\partial_\sigma\) and \(\mathbb E_\eta\) do commute, and the result is still zero.  
(Technically one needs a uniform integrability or dominated-convergence condition to justify exchanging limit and expectation; here it is satisfied automatically because the integrand is constant.)

---

### Where the earlier “entropy changes with \(\sigma\)” came from

What usually interests people in stochastic dynamics is not  
\(\mathbb E[h_\sigma^{\eta}(t)]\) (the **mean of the pathwise entropies**)  
but

\[
H_{\sigma}(t)
   := -\!\int \bar\rho_\sigma(x,t)\,\log\bar\rho_\sigma(x,t)\,dx,
\qquad
\bar\rho_\sigma:=\mathbb E_{\eta}\bigl[\rho_\sigma^{\eta}\bigr],
\tag{$\star$}
\]

the **entropy of the averaged density**.  
Because \(\bar\rho_\sigma\) is a *convolution* of \(\rho^{0}(\cdot,t)\) with a Gaussian of variance \(2\sigma^{2}t\),

\[
\bar\rho_\sigma(x,t)
   =\bigl(\rho^{0}(\cdot,t)*\mathcal N\bigl(0,2\sigma^{2}t I\bigr)\bigr)(x),
\]

its entropy increases with \(\sigma\) (mixing spreads mass).  
The derivative \(\partial_\sigma H_\sigma(t)\) is typically positive and captures the “true” noise-induced entropy production.

In symbols,

\[
\partial_\sigma\;H_\sigma(t)
      \neq
      \partial_\sigma\;\mathbb E_\eta[h_\sigma^{\eta}(t)],
\]
because \(H_\sigma(t)\) is **not** \(\mathbb E_\eta[h_\sigma^{\eta}(t)]\); the entropy operator is nonlinear, so
\[
H_\sigma(t)=\mathcal H\!\bigl[\mathbb E_\eta[\rho_\sigma^{\eta}]\bigr]
\quad\text{whereas}\quad
\mathbb E_\eta[h_\sigma^{\eta}(t)]=\mathbb E_\eta\bigl[\mathcal H[\rho_\sigma^{\eta}]\bigr].
\]

The two coincide only if the averaging kernel is a Dirac delta (i.e. \(\sigma=0\)).  
Thus there is no contradiction:  
*Derivatives and expectations commute for the object you originally asked about, but the object that carries \(\sigma\)-dependence is a different one.*

---

### Summary

* Yes, under standard regularity the interchange \(\partial_\sigma\mathbb E_\eta=\mathbb E_\eta\partial_\sigma\) is valid for the pathwise entropy, but both sides vanish.
* If you want an entropy that **does** feel the noise amplitude, you must first average the densities (get \(\bar\rho_\sigma\)) and only then take the entropy.  
  That quantity’s \(\sigma\)-derivative does **not** equal \(\mathbb E_\eta[\partial_\sigma h_\sigma^{\eta}]\), precisely because entropy is nonlinear.

parts:
Let  

\[
H_{\sigma}(t)\;=\;-\!\int_{\mathbb R^{n}}\bar\rho_{\sigma}(x,t)\,
                     \log\bar\rho_{\sigma}(x,t)\,dx,
\qquad 
\bar\rho_{\sigma}(x,t)
      =\bigl(\rho^{0}(\cdot,t)\!*\,\mathcal N\!\bigl(0,2\sigma^{2}tI\bigr)\bigr)(x),
\]

where \(\rho^{0}(\cdot,t)\) is the Liouville density of the **deterministic** flow and  
\(\mathcal N(0,2\sigma^{2}tI)\) is the centred Gaussian of variance \(2\sigma^{2}t\).

---

### 1 Re-parametrise by the effective variance  
Set  

\[
\alpha:=2\sigma^{2}t\;>\;0
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\bar\rho_{\sigma}=\bar\rho_{\alpha},
\quad
H_{\sigma}(t)=h(\alpha),
\]

so that \(h(\alpha)\) is just the entropy of a density blurred by a Gaussian
of variance \(\alpha\).

---

### 2 De Bruijn identity for Gaussian smoothing  
For every integrable density \(p\) and \(\alpha>0\):

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
\frac{d}{d\alpha}h(\alpha)
      =\frac12\,I\bigl(p*\mathcal N(0,\alpha I)\bigr)},
\tag{A}
\]

with Fisher information  

\[
I(q)=\int_{\mathbb R^{n}}q(x)\,\|\nabla\log q(x)\|^{2}\,dx.
\]

Identity (A) holds under the mild regularity required for the
heat equation (e.g. \(p\) has finite second moment).

---

### 3 Chain rule back to \(\sigma\)

\[
\frac{\partial H_{\sigma}(t)}{\partial\sigma}
    =\frac{dh}{d\alpha}\,\frac{d\alpha}{d\sigma}
    =\bigl[\tfrac12\,I(\bar\rho_{\sigma})\bigr]\bigl[4\sigma t\bigr]
    =2\sigma t\,I\!\bigl(\bar\rho_{\sigma}\bigr).
\]

---

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
\partial_{\sigma}H_{\sigma}(t)
      =2\,\sigma\,t
        \int_{\mathbb R^{n}}\bar\rho_{\sigma}(x,t)\,
             \bigl\|\nabla\log\bar\rho_{\sigma}(x,t)\bigr\|^{2}\,dx.}
\]

---

### 4 Interpretation  

* \(I(\bar\rho_{\sigma})\) measures how sharply the **noise-smoothed** density varies.
* The factor \(2\sigma t\) reflects how an infinitesimal change in the
noise amplitude \(\sigma\) widens the Gaussian kernel
(\(\alpha=2\sigma^{2}t\)).
* For small \(\sigma\) one gets the first-order expansion  

  \[
  H_{\sigma}(t)=H_{0}(t)+\sigma^{2}t\,I\bigl(\rho^{0}(\cdot,t)\bigr)+o(\sigma^{2}),
  \]
  using \(I(\bar\rho_{\sigma})\xrightarrow[\sigma\to0]{}I(\rho^{0})\).

This formula is the precise way \(\partial_{\sigma}\) “acts on” the averaged
entropy \(H_{\sigma}(t)\).

thoughts.content: The user is asking about the relation between coarse-grained entropy \(H(\varepsilon,t)\) and differential entropy \(h(t)\) of an evolving density, with information dimension \(D_I\). They're curious about the limit as \(\varepsilon\) approaches 0 and \(t \to \infty\), specifically regarding the subsequences. I think they’re questioning if the limit of the ratio \(\lim_{\varepsilon\to 0} \lim_{t\to\infty} [H(\varepsilon,t)/(-\log \varepsilon)]\) depends on the order of taking limits. Interesting question!

The user asks whether the subsequence of \(\varepsilon\) matters when taking the limit to \(\varepsilon = 0\). For most dynamical attractors with good properties (ergodic measures, exact dimensional measures), the limit exists and subsequences don't matter. However, for fractals or multifractal sets, differences may arise between limsup and liminf, which means subsequences could matter. The conditions for independence of subsequences only hold when the measure is exact dimensional. I'll ensure this is explained rigorously but concisely.

parts:
First clear up the sign.  For a partition of space into cubes of side ε,
\[
H(\varepsilon,t)\;=\;-\!\sum_i p_i(t)\log p_i(t)
\]
and, whenever the (time-dependent) density admits an ordinary differential entropy \(h(t)\),

\[
H(\varepsilon,t)=h(t)\;+\;D_I\,\log\!\frac1\varepsilon\;+\;o(1)\qquad(\varepsilon\to0).
\]

So the coefficient of \(\log(1/\varepsilon)\) is \(+D_I\), not \(-D_I\).

---

### What happens when \(t\to\infty\)?

Let \(\mu_\infty\) be any weak limit of the evolving measures (on the attractor).  Set
\[
H_\varepsilon(\mu_\infty)=\!\!-\sum_{i} \mu_\infty(C_i)\,\log\mu_\infty(C_i).
\]
Define

\[
\underline D_I=\liminf_{\varepsilon\to0}\frac{H_\varepsilon(\mu_\infty)}{\log(1/\varepsilon)},\qquad
\overline D_I=\limsup_{\varepsilon\to0}\frac{H_\varepsilon(\mu_\infty)}{\log(1/\varepsilon)}.
\]

* **If \(\underline D_I=\overline D_I\)** (the usual *information dimension* exists), the ratio converges, so *every* sequence \(\varepsilon_k\downarrow0\) gives the same limit; subsequences are irrelevant.

* **If they differ**, the limit in general **depends on the subsequence**.  One can always pick two sequences \(\{\varepsilon_k\}\) and \(\{\tilde\varepsilon_k\}\) with distinct accumulation points equal to \(\underline D_I\) and \(\overline D_I\).

---

### When is the subsequence issue avoided?

A Borel probability measure \(\mu\) on \(\mathbb R^n\) is **exact-dimensional** if the local dimension
\[
d_\mu(x)=\lim_{r\to0}\frac{\log\mu(B_r(x))}{\log r}
\]
exists and is constant for \(\mu\)-a.e. \(x\).  Exact dimensionality implies \(\underline D_I=\overline D_I=d_\mu\); hence the \(\varepsilon\)-limit is unique.

* **Typical smooth hyperbolic dynamical systems** (uniformly expanding maps, Anosov diffeomorphisms, Axiom-A flows) with their SRB measures are exact-dimensional (Ledrappier–Young, 1985; Young, 1983).  
* **Gibbs measures** for Hölder potentials, equilibrium states, and many self-similar measures with the open-set condition are exact-dimensional.  
* For such systems, once \(t\) is large enough that the distribution is close to the invariant measure, \(H(\varepsilon,t)\) has the unique slope \(D_I\) no matter how \(\varepsilon\to0\).

---

### When can the slope oscillate?

If the measure is **not** exact-dimensional, oscillations are common.  Classic examples:

* A weighted sum of two Cantor measures with incommensurate scaling ratios;  
* Certain self-similar measures failing the open-set condition;  
* Non-ergodic limits obtained by averaging over several SRB components.

For these, \(H_\varepsilon/\log(1/\varepsilon)\) can wander between two values, so picking different \(\varepsilon\)-subsequences changes the limit.

---

### Bottom line

*Write limits in the order you intend:*  

\[
D_I\;=\;\lim_{\varepsilon\to0}\frac{1}{\log(1/\varepsilon)}\;
        \Bigl[\;\lim_{t\to\infty} H(\varepsilon,t)\Bigr]
\]

exists and is subsequence-independent **iff** the limiting measure is exact-dimensional (or, at minimum, \(\underline D_I=\overline D_I\)).  
Otherwise the two-parameter limit is only defined through \(\limsup\) or by fixing a particular sequence \(\varepsilon_k\downarrow0\).

For example, the measure μ = 1/2 μ_α + 1/2 μ_β, where μ_α and μ_β are self-similar Cantor measures with different dimensions (α ≠ β). As we apply a coarse-grained entropy at scale ε, the contributions from each set will dominate depending on how ε compares to their scales, creating oscillations.

As ε approaches 0, it doesn't have a single limit; different subsequences approaching zero (for example, ε = 1/n or ε = 1/(2n)) can yield different values because of the oscillations. Likewise, a function like f(ε) = (-1)^{\lfloor 1/ε \rfloor} demonstrates similar behavior, with limits that depend on the subsequence choice.

The user asks for a basic and abstract example of different subsequences yielding different limits. A simple example is the sequence f(ε) = sin(1/ε). For certain subsequences like ε_n = 1/(π/2 + 2πn), the function approaches 1, while others like ε_n' = 1/(3π/2 + 2πn) approach -1. A similar concept is shown with (-1)^n, where even n gives a limit of 1 and odd n gives -1. The key idea is that a limit only exists if all subsequences yield the same value.

parts:
A classic way to see “subsequence–dependent limits” is just to look at an **oscillating sequence or function whose full limit does not exist**.  
Everything below is self-contained—no dimension, no entropy.

---

### 1. Purely discrete sequence

Let  
\[
x_n = (-1)^n , \qquad n=1,2,\dots
\]

* The **even index subsequence** \(x_{2k}=(-1)^{2k}=+1\) converges to \(+1\).
* The **odd index subsequence** \(x_{2k+1}=(-1)^{2k+1}=-1\) converges to \(-1\).

Because two subsequences have different limits, the original sequence has **no limit**.

---

### 2. Function of a continuous parameter approaching zero

Define  
\[
f(\varepsilon)=\sin\!\bigl(\tfrac1{\varepsilon}\bigr),\quad 0<\varepsilon<1.
\]

Take two sequences of positive numbers shrinking to zero:

* \(\varepsilon_k = \dfrac1{\pi/2+2\pi k}\;\;\;\;\;\;(\)so\(\; \tfrac1{\varepsilon_k} = \tfrac{\pi}{2}+2\pi k )\)

  Then \(f(\varepsilon_k)=\sin(\pi/2)=+1\), so this subsequence tends to \(+1\).

* \(\tilde\varepsilon_k = \dfrac1{3\pi/2+2\pi k}\;\;(\tfrac1{\tilde\varepsilon_k}= \tfrac{3\pi}{2}+2\pi k)\)

  Here \(f(\tilde\varepsilon_k)=\sin(3\pi/2)=-1\), giving limit \(-1\).

Again, different subsequences of the same approach to \(\varepsilon=0\) deliver **different limits**.

---

### 3. A sequence of probability measures

Let \(\delta_0\) and \(\delta_1\) be point masses at \(0\) and \(1\).  Define

\[
\mu_n=\begin{cases}
\delta_0 & n\ \text{even},\\[4pt]
\delta_1 & n\ \text{odd}.
\end{cases}
\]

* The even subsequence \(\{\mu_{2k}\}\) converges (in the weak-\(*\) sense) to \(\delta_0\).
* The odd subsequence \(\{\mu_{2k+1}\}\) converges to \(\delta_1\).

There is no single limiting measure for the full sequence.

---

### Moral

Whenever a limit is defined by **first taking a parameter to zero (or infinity)**, the result is unique **only if every sequence tending to that endpoint yields the same limit**. If you can cook up two subsequences with different limits—as in the three examples above—then the overall limit does not exist, and any formula that assumes it does must specify *which* subsequence (or use limsup/liminf instead).

Frisson states in a preliminary result of his theory that the stationary solution of a Fokker Planck equation with constant covariance \Gamma implies a relation between \nabla \log p and f, the deterministic dynamics. In one line, what is that relation

thoughts.summary: Answering the question on Fokker-Planck relation
thoughts.content:
The relation between the gradient of log stationary density \( p \) and the drift \( f \) is given by:

\[
f = \frac{1}{2} \Gamma \nabla \log p + k
\]

Here, \( k \) is a divergence-free term with respect to \( p \). Under detailed balance (gradient flow), this term is zero. This comes from the stationary solution of the Fokker-Planck equation for isotropic noise.

parts:
Not in general.  
The matrix \(Q\) is fixed by the identity  
\[
f(x)\;=\;\Bigl(\tfrac12\,\Gamma+Q\Bigr)\,\nabla\!\log\rho_\infty(x),
\qquad 
\nabla\!\cdot\!\bigl(Q\nabla\rho_\infty\bigr)=0 ,
\tag{1}
\]

so once \(f\) and \(\Gamma\) are specified, \(Q\) has to be chosen so that (1) holds for the stationary density \(\rho_\infty\).  Because \(\rho_\infty\) itself depends on \(\Gamma\) (via the steady‐state Fokker–Planck equation) the concrete entries of \(Q\) generally inherit that dependence.

---

### Quick illustration (linear drift)

Let \(f(x)=A x\) with constant matrix \(A\) and keep \(\Gamma\succ0\) constant.  
The Ornstein–Uhlenbeck stationary covariance \(\Sigma\) solves  
\[
A\Sigma+\Sigma A^{\!\top}=\Gamma .
\]
Here \(\nabla\log\rho_\infty(x)=-\Sigma^{-1}x\).  Plugging into (1):

\[
A x
= \Bigl(\tfrac12\,\Gamma+Q\Bigr)(-\Sigma^{-1}x)
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
A = -\tfrac12\,\Gamma\,\Sigma^{-1}-Q\Sigma^{-1}.
\]

For a fixed drift matrix \(A\), changing \(\Gamma\) forces \(\Sigma\) to change, and the last term shows that \(Q\Sigma^{-1}\) must adjust accordingly.  Thus \(Q\) cannot stay the same unless very special commutation conditions hold (e.g.\ \(\Gamma\Sigma^{-1}\) happens to vary inside the skew‐symmetric subspace already spanned by a \(\Gamma\)-independent \(Q\)).

---

### When can \(Q\) be \(\Gamma\)-independent?

- **Gradient flow**: if \(f=\tfrac12\,\Gamma\nabla\log\rho_\infty\) already (no rotational component), then \(Q=0\) for every \(\Gamma\).  
- **Separated decomposition**: if there is a skew‐symmetric \(Q_0\) with  
  \(f = \tfrac12\,\Gamma\nabla\log\rho_\infty + Q_0\nabla\log\rho_\infty\) **for all** admissible \(\Gamma\), then \(Q=Q_0\).  
  This requires a very rigid structure: \(Q_0\nabla\log\rho_\infty\) must remain unchanged as \(\Gamma\) varies, which rarely holds outside special linear or integrable cases.

In typical nonlinear systems the coupling in (1) makes \(Q\) an implicit function of \(\Gamma\).  What is \(\Gamma\)-independent is only the **property** of \(Q\): it must be constant in space and skew-symmetric so that \(\nabla\!\cdot(Q\nabla\rho_\infty)=0\); but its actual numerical values track the diffusion matrix through the stationary density.
How can I determine Q?

thoughts.content: To determine Q, we need to decompose the vector field f using the Helmholtz decomposition into gradient and divergence-free components based on the stationary density ρ∞. Q represents the divergence-free part, acting on ∇logρ. If we know ρ∞, we can compute Σ via least squares and minimize the difference between f and (Γ/2 + Q)∇logρ. Q is antisymmetric, so we project the covariance matrix between f and ∇logρ onto the antisymmetric subspace to solve for Q.

thoughts.summary: Solving for Q in linear systems
thoughts.content: We define matrix C as the expected value of f(∇logρ)^T, and relate C to (Γ/2 + Q)S, where S is the covariance matrix of ∇logρ. Solving for Q, we get Q = C * S⁻¹ - Γ/2, and project it onto the antisymmetric space. If ρ∞ is unknown, we can solve a PDE for Q. Alternatively, we could compute ρ∞ from Fokker-Planck, compute the score vector, and solve for Q using least-squares minimization, ensuring antisymmetry and considering identifiability constraints.

parts:
Below is a constructive way to extract \(Q\) from data you either **know** or can **compute numerically** once the system has reached its stationary state.

---

### 1.  Gather the two ingredients that appear in  
\[
f(x)=\Bigl(\tfrac12\,\Gamma+Q\Bigr)\,\nabla\!\log\rho_\infty(x).
\]

* **The score field**  
  \(\displaystyle u(x)=\nabla\!\log\rho_\infty(x)\).

* **The drift field**  
  \(f(x)\).

If \(\rho_\infty\) is not available in closed form, obtain it by solving the stationary Fokker–Planck equation  
\(\nabla\!\cdot\bigl(-f\rho_\infty+\tfrac12\,\Gamma\nabla\rho_\infty\bigr)=0\)  
(e.g. on a grid, with Monte-Carlo, or spectral methods), then differentiate to get \(u\).

---

### 2.  Form two stationary covariances

\[
\Sigma \;=\; \int_{\mathbb R^n} u(x)\,u(x)^{\!\top}\,\rho_\infty(x)\,dx
\quad\text{and}\quad
C \;=\; \int_{\mathbb R^n} f(x)\,u(x)^{\!\top}\,\rho_\infty(x)\,dx .
\]

* \(\Sigma\) is symmetric positive-semidefinite (“Fisher information” matrix of the measure).  
* \(C\) is a drift–score cross-covariance.

---

### 3.  Solve the linear system for \(Q\)

Because \(f=(\tfrac12\Gamma+Q)u\), multiplying by \(u^{\!\top}\) and averaging gives

\[
C \;=\;\tfrac12\,\Gamma\,\Sigma \;+\;Q\,\Sigma .
\]

Provided \(\Sigma\) has full rank (or using its Moore–Penrose pseudoinverse \(\Sigma^{+}\) otherwise):

\[
\boxed{\;Q_\text{raw}\;=\;C\,\Sigma^{+}\;-\;\tfrac12\,\Gamma\;}
\]

---

### 4.  Enforce the skew-symmetry constraint

Only the **antisymmetric** part of \(Q_\text{raw}\) is admissible:

\[
\boxed{\;
Q \;=\;\tfrac12\bigl(Q_\text{raw}-Q_\text{raw}^{\!\top}\bigr).
\;}

\]

This \(Q\) is constant, skew-symmetric, and by construction satisfies
\(f=(\tfrac12\Gamma+Q)u\) in a **least-squares sense** whenever \(\Sigma\) is not full rank.

---

### 5.  Check identifiability

* If \(\Sigma\) is nonsingular, \(Q\) is **unique**.
* If \(\Sigma\) is singular, \(Q\) is unique only in the subspace spanned by the score vectors; outside that subspace you can add any constant skew-symmetric matrix that annihilates \(\Sigma\).

---

### 6.  Special cases

* **Gradient systems**: if \(f=\tfrac12\Gamma u\), then \(C=\tfrac12\Gamma\Sigma\) and the construction gives \(Q=0\).
* **Linear Ornstein–Uhlenbeck**: \(f(x)=Ax\), \(\rho_\infty=\mathcal N(0,\Sigma)\) with \(A\Sigma+\Sigma A^{\!\top}=\Gamma\).  
  One finds \(Q=\tfrac12(\Gamma\Sigma^{-1}-\Sigma^{-1}\Gamma)\), reproducing the standard reversible/irreversible split of \(A\).

---

#### In practice
1. **Simulate** long trajectories, record samples of \(x\), estimate \(\rho_\infty\) (or directly \(u\)) and \(f(x)\).
2. **Accumulate** empirical averages for \(C\) and \(\Sigma\).
3. **Evaluate** the two boxed formulas above.

That procedure yields the unique stationary \(Q\) compatible with the given \(f\) and \(\Gamma\).
How about this: how does \rho(x,t+dt) depends on \Gamma, in terms of \rho(x,t)?

thoughts.content:
The user is asking for the relationship between \(\rho(x,t+dt)\) and \(\rho(x,t)\), showing dependence on \(\Gamma\) (constant covariance) in a Fokker-Planck equation. The approach involves considering an infinitesimal time step. First-order in \(dt\), the formula for \(\rho(x,t+dt)\) is:

\[
\rho(x,t+dt) = \rho(x,t) + dt \left[ -\nabla \cdot (f \rho) + \frac{1}{2} \nabla \cdot (\Gamma \nabla \rho) \right]
\]

Alternatively, the propagator form \( \rho(x,t+dt) = e^{dt L} \rho(x,t) \) is also viable. Precision will be key.

parts:
For an SDE  
\[
\mathrm dX_t = f(X_t)\,\mathrm dt + \sqrt{\Gamma}\,\mathrm dW_t ,
\qquad \Gamma\in\mathbb R^{n\times n}\text{ constant and symmetric},
\]
the Kolmogorov forward (Fokker–Planck) generator is  
\[
\mathcal L := -\nabla\!\cdot(f\,\cdot) \;+\;\tfrac12\,\nabla\!\cdot\!\bigl(\Gamma\nabla(\,\cdot\,)\bigr).
\]

Hence, for a small time step \(dt\),

\[
\boxed{\;
\rho(x,t+dt)\;=\;\rho(x,t)\;+\;dt\,\Bigl[-\nabla\!\cdot\!\bigl(f(x)\,\rho(x,t)\bigr)
\;+\;\tfrac12\,\nabla\!\cdot\!\bigl(\Gamma\nabla\rho(x,t)\bigr)\Bigr]\;+\;O(dt^{2})\;}. \tag{*}
\]

Equation \((*)\) shows:

* **Drift term** (independent of \(\Gamma\)): \(-\nabla\!\cdot\bigl(f\rho\bigr)\,dt\) transports probability along the deterministic flow.
* **Diffusion term** (linear in \(\Gamma\)): \(\tfrac12\,\nabla\!\cdot\bigl(\Gamma\nabla\rho\bigr)\,dt\) spreads probability, with the strength and anisotropy set by \(\Gamma\).

Equivalently, to first order in \(dt\) you can view the update as deterministic advection followed by Gaussian smoothing:

\[
\rho(x,t+dt)\;=\;\int_{\mathbb R^{n}}\!
\frac{\exp\!\bigl[-\tfrac12(y-x)^{\!\top}\Gamma^{-1}(y-x)/(dt)\bigr]}{(2\pi dt)^{n/2}\sqrt{\det\Gamma}}\;
\rho\bigl(y-f(y)\,dt,t\bigr)\,dy\;+\;O(dt^{2}),
\]

making the dependence on \(\Gamma\) explicit through the Gaussian kernel.
And what is the same relation for \nabla \log rho?

thoughts.content:
The user is working with the Fokker-Planck equation and wants to express how the gradient of log ρ changes with respect to the covariance matrix Γ. The first step is identifying the equation:

∇ log ρ(x,t+dt) = ∇ log ρ(x,t) + dt [terms involving f, Γ, ρ]. 

Then, using the PDE and derivative of ρ, we can express ρ(t+dt) and compute ∇ log ρ. The process leads to an approximation in terms of log ρ and additional terms involving dt.

We are working through the Fokker-Planck equation to express ∇ log ρ(t+dt). The terms start to break down like this: 

First, we compute the Lρ/ρ term, which involves terms like ∇·(f ρ) and ∇·(Γ∇ρ). For simplification, we express ∇ρ as ρg.

The divergence calculation leads to an expression that ultimately simplifies to: ∇·(Γ ρ g) = (Γ^T ∇)(ρ g). 

Although there's a little potential for confusion in the steps, this process will yield the needed terms!

The goal here is to compute the gradient of log ρ at time t + dt, starting with the given expressions for Lρ and its components. First, we expanded terms like ∇ log ρ and the divergence of Γ∇ρ. After simplifying, we arrived at an expression for Lρ/ρ, and started considering how to compute the gradient ∇(Lρ/ρ). 

The expression involves terms like the constant diffusion matrix Γ and drift f, and after expanding, we get a form resembling Itô calculus. We'll need to keep track of the higher-order terms to refine the result.

Let’s simplify the gradient relation for log ρ at t + dt. We started with the PDE for u = log ρ and derived the gradient expression step by step. First, the time derivative of u gives a combination of drift and diffusion terms. Taking the gradient of the updated u expression leads to the final formula: 

∇ log ρ(x,t+dt) = ∇ log ρ(x,t) + dt ∇[ -∇·f - f·∇ log ρ + 1/2 ∇·(Γ ∇ log ρ) + 1/2 (∇ log ρ)^T Γ ∇ log ρ ] + O(dt^2).

Let's finalize this clean expression!

parts:
Starting from the same first-order expansion

\[
\rho(x,t+dt)=\rho(x,t)
+dt\Bigl[-\nabla\!\cdot\!\bigl(f\,\rho\bigr)
+\tfrac12\,\nabla\!\cdot\!\bigl(\Gamma\nabla\rho\bigr)\Bigr]
+\mathcal O(dt^{2}),
\]

write \(u=\log\rho\) so that \(\rho=e^{u}\) and \(g:=\nabla u=\nabla\log\rho\).  
Because \(\partial_t u=(\partial_t\rho)/\rho\), one obtains

\[
\partial_t u=-\nabla\!\cdot f-f\!\cdot\!g
+\tfrac12\,\nabla\!\cdot(\Gamma g)
+\tfrac12\,g^{\!\top}\Gamma g.
\]

Taking a spatial gradient and integrating one time step \(dt\) gives the desired update:

\[
\boxed{\;
\nabla\log\rho(x,t+dt)=\nabla\log\rho(x,t)
+dt\,\nabla\!\Bigl[
-\nabla\!\cdot f
-\!f\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho
+\tfrac12\,\nabla\!\cdot(\Gamma\nabla\log\rho)
+\tfrac12\,(\nabla\log\rho)^{\!\top}\Gamma\nabla\log\rho
\Bigr]_{t}
+\mathcal O(dt^{2})\;} .
\]

The diffusion matrix \(\Gamma\) enters **linearly** through the Laplacian-type term  
\(\frac12\nabla\!\cdot(\Gamma\nabla\log\rho)\) and **quadratically** through  
\(\frac12(\nabla\log\rho)^{\!\top}\Gamma\nabla\log\rho\); the deterministic drift \(f\) contributes only through advection and the divergence of \(f\).

1. **Domains and order of limits**

   * When you write \(g(c,\infty)\) do you really mean the limit \(\displaystyle\lim_{t\to\infty}g(c,t)\) taken first, followed by \(c\to0\)?

2. **Behaviour of the auxiliary functions near the singular point**

4. **Constants and neglected orders**

Once those pieces are pinned down we can decide whether, for example, a matched-asymptotic expansion or a small-\(c\) renormalisation is the right tool, and—crucially—avoid the tempting wrong turns you mentioned.

parts:
Here is what can and cannot be said given only the information you have supplied.  
(Throughout, “ \(c\!\downarrow\!0\) ” means the one-sided limit \(c\to0^{+}\); \(t\) is taken *fixed but large*.)

---

### 1  Minimal hypotheses that let \(D\) be isolated from \(g\)

You have
\[
f(c,t)=t\,h(0)+D\log c+\mathcal O(1),\qquad  
g(c,t)=t\,h(c)+t\,I(c)+\mathcal O(1),\qquad (0<c\ll1,\;t\gg1),
\]
with  
\(g(0,t)=f(0,t)\equiv t\,h(0)+D\log0\)(divergent).

To extract the coefficient \(D\) **solely from \(g\)** you must impose at least

\[
\text{(H1)}\quad h(c)-h(0)=o(\log c)\quad(c\!\downarrow\!0),\qquad
\text{(H2)}\quad I(c)=o(\log c)\quad(c\!\downarrow\!0).
\]

*If either of these fails, a logarithmic term coming from \(h\) or \(I\) can mimic the
\(D\log c\) piece and \(D\) is not separately identifiable.*

---

### 2  A formula for \(D\) under (H1)–(H2)

With (H1)–(H2) in place,
\[
g(0,t)-g(c,t)=D\log c+o(\log c)\qquad(c\!\downarrow\!0).
\]

Hence for any fixed large \(t\)

\[
\boxed{\;
D=\lim_{c\to0^{+}}\frac{g(0,t)-g(c,t)}{\log c}\;} \tag{2.1}
\]

The ratio is \(t\)-independent because the entire \(t\)-dependence of
\(g\) cancels in the numerator.

---

### 3  Equivalent derivative form

If the one-sided derivative \(\partial_{c}g(c,t)\) exists for \(c>0\),
then, still under (H1)–(H2),

\[
D=-\lim_{c\to0^{+}}c\,\partial_{c}g(c,t). \tag{2.2}
\]

This is just the distributional statement that the jump of a function with a
\(D\log c\) singularity is produced by a point-mass \(D\,\delta(c)\) in its
\(c\)-derivative.

---

### 4  What if (H1) or (H2) is violated?

* If \(h(c)-h(0)\sim\alpha\log c\) or \(I(c)\sim\beta\log c\) as \(c\!\downarrow\!0\),
then \(g(0,t)-g(c,t)=(D-\alpha t-\beta t)\log c+\dots\).  
Nothing short of separate knowledge of \(\alpha\) or \(\beta\) can disentangle \(D\).

* If \(h(c)-h(0)\) or \(I(c)\) diverge more slowly than \(\log c\)
(e.g.\ powers \(c^{\gamma}\), \(\gamma>0\)), formula (2.1) still works because
\(\log c\) dominates any such term.

---

### 5  Why joint \(c\)\,-\(\,t\) limits are not helpful here

Because \(f\) and \(g\) are matched *only at the single point \(c=0\)*,
no joint scaling \(c=c(t)\) can supply extra information—the logarithmic
divergence sits entirely in the vertical jump of \(g\) at \(c=0\).
Working first at fixed \(t\) and then sending \(c\to0^{+}\) is therefore
essential.

---

### 6  Recommended next check

Confirm empirically or analytically that your concrete \(h(c)\) and \(I(c)\)
indeed satisfy (H1)–(H2); if they do, formula (2.1) (or (2.2)) gives \(D\)
directly from \(g\).  
If they do **not**, you will need additional structural input—there is no
universal way to read \(D\) off \(g\) alone.

---

It seems the user is asking if it's possible to interchange limits and derivatives with respect to different variables or parameters. They may have meant "variables" since they mentioned swapping derivatives with respect to parameters like log epsilon. 

They might be referring to situations like differentiating under the limit sign, where certain conditions allow swapping the limit and derivative, such as in some limit cases of sequences or functions.

thoughts.summary: Interpreting conditions for interchanging derivative and limit
thoughts.content: It seems thematically, the user wants conditions on when you can interchange limits and derivatives. To swap them, we need rigorous conditions like uniform convergence and dominated convergence. There are powerful theorems like Moore-Osgood, Leibniz’ rule, and others that can help, especially if sequences of functions converge at the right rates (pointwise, uniform convergence of derivatives). I might also need specific conditions like uniform boundedness to differentiate properly across limits. I’ll provide a clear, step-by-step answer with examples.

parts:
In short: **yes—but only when a fairly tight set of regularity or domination hypotheses is met.**  Below is a compact “check-list” that I use when I need to pass a derivative through a limit (or vice-versa) in analysis of dynamical systems and stochastic‐noise asymptotics.  I state a clean theorem first, then explain why each hypothesis matters and give a quick failure example.

---

### A handy theorem (one–dimensional parameter)

Let \((f_t)_{t\ge 0}\subset C^{1}(I)\) with \(I\subset\mathbb R\) an open interval, and fix \(x_{0}\in I\).

Assume  

1. **Pointwise (or uniform) convergence of the functions**  
   \[
     f_t(x)\;\xrightarrow[t\to\infty]{}\;f(x)\qquad\forall x\in I ,
   \]
   and \(f_t(x_0)\) converges as \(t\to\infty\).

2. **Uniform convergence of the derivatives on compacts**  
   \[
     \sup_{x\in K}\,|\,\partial_x f_t(x)-g(x)\,|\;\xrightarrow[t\to\infty]{}0
     \quad\text{for every compact }K\subset I ,
   \]
   for some \(g\in C(I)\).

Then  

* \(f\in C^{1}(I)\),
* \(f'(x)=g(x)\) for all \(x\in I\), and  
* **interchange is legal:** \(\displaystyle\partial_x\bigl[\lim_{t\to\infty}f_t(x)\bigr]=\lim_{t\to\infty}\partial_x f_t(x)\).

> This is a standard “uniform convergence of derivatives” theorem; it is often presented as a corollary of the Arzelà–Ascoli compactness theorem and sometimes called the **Moore–Osgood interchange theorem**.

---

### Why each assumption is needed  

| Hypothesis | What can go wrong if dropped |
|------------|-----------------------------|
| Pointwise convergence of \(f_t\) | You might have a well-behaved derivative limit but no candidate function \(f\) to differentiate. |
| Convergence at one basepoint \(x_0\) | Prevents the constant of integration from drifting with \(t\). |
| **Uniform** convergence of \(f_t'\) on compacts | Guarantees that any error bound is independent of \(t\); without it, small oscillations of \(f_t'\) that shrink pointwise but not uniformly can destroy differentiability of \(f\). |

---

### A quick counter-example

\[
f_t(x)\;=\;\frac{\sin(tx^{2})}{t}.
\]

* \(f_t(x)\to 0\) pointwise, so the limit exists.  
* \(\partial_x f_t(x)=2x\cos(tx^{2})\) does **not** converge pointwise (it oscillates forever).  
* Interchange would predict a zero derivative, yet the true limit function is identically \(0\) (so derivative is indeed \(0\)), but the interchange fails because \(\partial_x f_t\) has no limit.

The missing ingredient is the uniform-convergence‐of‐derivatives assumption.

---

### The dominated-convergence version (more common in stochastic work)

For families \(f(t,\varepsilon)\) where \(t\to\infty\) and you want \(\displaystyle\partial_\varepsilon\lim_{t\to\infty}f\), replace uniform convergence by a **dominated bound** on the \(\varepsilon\)-derivative:

Suppose  

1. \(f(t,\varepsilon)\xrightarrow[t\to\infty]{}f_\infty(\varepsilon)\) for every \(\varepsilon\) in an open set \(E\subset\mathbb R\).  
2. \(\partial_\varepsilon f(t,\varepsilon)\) exists for all \(t\) large enough and  
   \[
      |\partial_\varepsilon f(t,\varepsilon)|\;\le\;M(\varepsilon)\quad
      \text{with } M\in L^\infty_{\mathrm{loc}}(E),
   \]
   and \(\partial_\varepsilon f(t,\varepsilon)\to g(\varepsilon)\) pointwise as \(t\to\infty\).

Then by the **dominated (Lebesgue) convergence theorem** you still get  
\[
\partial_\varepsilon f_\infty(\varepsilon)=g(\varepsilon)=\lim_{t\to\infty}\partial_\varepsilon f(t,\varepsilon).
\]

The condition \(|\partial_\varepsilon f|\le M\) uniform in \(t\) is the analogue of uniform convergence—it lets us dominate the error term when differentiating an \(\varepsilon\)-difference quotient.

---

### Practical rule of thumb

When you see  
\[
\partial_\varepsilon\bigl[\;\lim_{t\to\infty} F(t,\varepsilon)\bigr],
\]
check one of these quickly:

1. **Uniformity:** \(\partial_\varepsilon F(t,\varepsilon)\) converges **uniformly on every compact in \(\varepsilon\)**.  
2. **Domination:** \(\partial_\varepsilon F(t,\varepsilon)\) is dominated by an integrable majorant \(M(\varepsilon)\) that does not depend on \(t\), and pointwise convergence holds.  

If either is satisfied, swap away.

---

### Connection to your small-noise/large-time problems

In the stochastic‐dynamical setting you often have  
\[
F(t,\sigma)=\mathbb E_\sigma[\varphi(X_t)],
\]
with \(\sigma\) the noise amplitude and want \(\partial_\sigma\lim_{t\to\infty}F(t,\sigma)\).

* Prove a **uniform exponential‐mixing bound** (gives domination).  
* Show that the derivative \(\partial_\sigma\mathcal L_\sigma\) of the Fokker–Planck semigroup is **bounded on an appropriate Banach space**; this supplies an \(M\).  

Once those are in place, the dominated‐convergence theorem lets you interchange the derivative and the \(t\to\infty\) limit safely.

---

### Take-away

> **Interchanging a limit with a derivative is legal if the derivative family behaves _uniformly_ (or is uniformly dominated) in the limiting parameter.**  
> Otherwise, keep them in the order they appear or expect surprises.

Feel free to point me at the exact \(F(t,\varepsilon)\) you have in mind, and I can verify the hypotheses directly.

thoughts.summary: Addressing pointwise convergence and swapping limits
thoughts.content: The user is asking about whether they can interchange the limit and derivative when the derivative with respect to x exists for each t, and the derivative converges pointwise as t → ∞. In general, pointwise convergence of derivatives is not enough to guarantee that the derivative of the limit is the same as the limit itself. This type of operation would require more conditions, such as uniform convergence or dominated convergence, to be valid.

To swap the limit and derivative, we need stronger conditions than just pointwise convergence of the derivatives. For instance, uniform convergence of the derivatives or a dominated bound is typically needed. In my reasoning, if the derivatives converge, we can approximate the function by integrating the limiting derivative, but only under certain conditions (like uniform convergence). Without uniform convergence, we could have cases where the limit function is not differentiable or its derivative doesn’t match the limiting derivative.

parts:
**Not in general.**  
Knowing only that  

* each \(f_t(\cdot)\) is differentiable in \(x\), and  
* the derivatives \(\partial_x f_t(x)\) converge (point-wise) to some limit \(g(x)\),

is **not sufficient** to guarantee  

\[
\partial_x\!\Bigl[\;\lim_{t\to\infty}f_t(x)\Bigr]
=\lim_{t\to\infty}\partial_x f_t(x).
\]

Extra uniformity or domination hypotheses are needed.  
Below is the minimal “safe recipe” and a counter-example showing why you need it.

---

### What *is* sufficient  

Let \(I\subset\mathbb R\) be open.  Suppose

1. **Pointwise limit exists**  
   \[
   f_t(x)\xrightarrow[t\to\infty]{}f(x)\quad\forall x\in I.
   \]

2. **Uniform control of derivatives**  
   For every compact \(K\subset I\) there is a constant \(M_K\) such that  
   \[
     |\partial_x f_t(x)|\le M_K\quad\forall x\in K,\;\forall t,
   \]
   and  
   \[
     \sup_{x\in K}\bigl|\partial_x f_t(x)-g(x)\bigr|\xrightarrow[t\to\infty]{}0.
   \]

Then (a standard consequence of the Arzelà–Ascoli theorem, often labelled the **Moore–Osgood interchange theorem**):

\[
f\in C^{1}(I),\qquad f'(x)=g(x),\qquad
\partial_x\lim_{t\to\infty}f_t=\lim_{t\to\infty}\partial_x f_t.
\]

A dominated-convergence variant: replace the uniform bound \(M_K\) by a locally integrable majorant \(M(x)\) that is independent of \(t\); the conclusion still holds.

---

### Why pointwise convergence of derivatives alone fails  

Define for \(t\ge1\)

\[
f_t(x)=|x|^{1+1/t}.
\]

* **Derivative exists:**  
  \(\displaystyle\partial_x f_t(x)=(1+1/t)\,\mathrm{sgn}(x)\,|x|^{1/t}\) for \(x\ne0\).

* **Derivative limit:**  
  For every \(x\ne0\),
  \(\partial_x f_t(x)\xrightarrow[t\to\infty]{}\mathrm{sgn}(x)=:g(x).\)

* **Function limit:**  
  \(f_t(x)\xrightarrow[t\to\infty]{}|x|=:f(x).\)

Yet \(f(x)=|x|\) is **not differentiable at \(x=0\).**  
So the limit of the derivatives exists everywhere except \(0\), but \(f\) itself fails to have a derivative there, contradicting the desired interchange.

The missing ingredient is the uniform (or dominated) control of \(\partial_x f_t\); near \(x=0\) the bound blows up as \(t\uparrow\infty\).

---

### Practical checklist  

Before swapping \(\displaystyle\partial_x\) and \(\displaystyle\lim_{t\to\infty}\),

1. **Does \(f_t\) converge?**  
2. **Is there a *uniform* (or dominated) bound on \(\partial_x f_t\)?**  
3. **Do the derivatives converge uniformly on compacts (or under domination)?**

If the answer to all three is “yes,” you can interchange.  
If any answer is “no,” look for a counter-example or supply the missing bound first.

Let’s say the we have two global dynamical attractors, one corresponds to the long time solution of an ODE and the other to the same ODE with some additive Gaussian noise. For really small noise, will expectations values over the attractor of observables always be identical?

thoughts.content: The user's question revolves around two dynamical attractors: a deterministic one and the same attractor with small Gaussian noise. I'll consider whether expectations for observables over both attractors converge as noise approaches zero. This involves examining the deterministic invariant measure versus the noisy stationary density. In the small-noise limit, the stationary density likely converges to the natural measure on the attractor, but this depends on conditions like whether the deterministic system has a unique measure and the type of noise applied.

thoughts.summary: Exploring the effect of noise on expectations
thoughts.content: In the case of a deterministic attractor, if it's not structurally stable or has multiple invariant sets, noise can shift the stationary measure and potentially smooth differences. They might converge, but only if the system has a unique SRB (ergodic physical measure), isotropic noise, and continuous observables. Otherwise, expectations may differ. However, noise can occasionally lead to transitions between attractors, creating expectations that weight invariant sets differently, depending on noise variance and observable characteristics. I’ll provide its mathematical expansion.

parts:
**Setup**

- Deterministic flow  
  \[
    \dot x = f(x), \qquad x\in\mathbb R^{n},
  \]
  with global attractor \(A\subset\mathbb R^{n}\).  
  Denote its (possibly singular) physical/SRB measure by \(\mu_{0}\).

- Small-noise perturbation (additive, isotropic, Gaussian)  
  \[
     dX_{t}=f(X_{t})\,dt+\sqrt{2}\,\sigma\,dW_{t}, \qquad \sigma>0 .
  \]
  Let \(\mu_{\sigma}\) be the unique stationary measure solving  
  \[
      \bigl(f\!\cdot\!\nabla+\sigma^{2}\Delta\bigr)^{*}\mu_{\sigma}=0 .
  \]

- Observable \(g\colon\mathbb R^{n}\to\mathbb R\) is bounded and continuous (or Hölder).  
  We ask whether
  \[
      \lim_{\sigma\to0}\int g\,d\mu_{\sigma}= \int g\,d\mu_{0}.
  \tag{★}
  \]

---

### 1.  When (★) **does** hold: _stochastically stable attractors_

A sufficient, classical set of hypotheses (Kifer 1988 ; Young 1990 ;  Bakhtin & Kifer 2004; Hairer & Mattingly 2011) is

1. **Uniqueness and ergodicity.**  
   The deterministic system possesses a *unique* SRB measure \(\mu_{0}\).

2. **Hyperbolic or partially hyperbolic structure** on \(A\) (Axiom A, uniformly expanding map, Anosov flow, or a uniformly attracting gradient-like flow).

3. **Topological stability of the attractor.**  
   No other invariant set is created by a \(C^{1}\)-small perturbation of \(f\).

Under these conditions the family \(\{\mu_{\sigma}\}_{\sigma>0}\) is *tight*; every weak limit as \(\sigma\to0\) is an invariant probability for the noiseless flow, hence must coincide with \(\mu_{0}\).  Consequently (★) holds and, moreover,^1

\[
    \Bigl|\int g\,d\mu_{\sigma}-\int g\,d\mu_{0}\Bigr|
      \;\le\; C_{g}\,\sigma^{2}+o(\sigma^{2}),
\]
provided \(g\in C^{2}\); the leading-order coefficient is obtained from a Poisson equation for \(L_{0}=f\!\cdot\!\nabla\).

---

### 2.  When (★) **fails**: _noise connects several deterministic invariant sets_

If the noiseless dynamics owns **more than one** physical measure (e.g. several attractors with disjoint basins), then even arbitrarily small noise allows exponentially rare jumps between basins (Freidlin–Wentzell).  The stationary density \(\mu_{\sigma}\) spreads over *all* metastable sets, and in the limit we get a **convex combination**
\[
     \mu_{\sigma}\;\xRightarrow[\sigma\to0]{}\;\bar\mu
     \;=\;\sum_{k} \alpha_{k}\,\mu_{0}^{(k)}, \qquad \sum_{k}\alpha_{k}=1,
\]
where each \(\mu_{0}^{(k)}\) is an SRB measure on the \(k\)-th attractor and the weights \(\alpha_{k}\) depend on the relative large-deviation rates for escaping the corresponding basins.  
Expectations of \(g\) converge to the **weighted** average, not to any single \(\mu_{0}^{(k)}\).  Thus (★) fails unless all \(\alpha_{k}\) but one vanish.

*Example.*  The gradient system \(\dot x=-\nabla V(x)\) with two wells.  
Without noise, \(\mu_{0}\) is a Dirac mass at whichever minimum lies in the initial basin.  
The SDE has stationary density \(\mu_{\sigma}(dx)\propto e^{-V(x)/\sigma^{2}}dx\).  
As \(\sigma\to0\), it converges to a **mixture of two deltas**, weighted by the relative depths of the wells.  Observables that distinguish the wells will have different expectations.

---

### 3.  Singular deterministic measures

Even when the deterministic SRB measure is *singular* (fractal), (★) can still hold for **continuous** \(g\).  
The reason is that weak convergence only “tests” measures against continuous functions, and the Gaussian convolution in the Fokker–Planck equation regularises \(\mu_{\sigma}\) without shifting its mass away from \(A\).  
However, for *discontinuous* or *unbounded* observables (e.g. indicator of a Cantor slice) the limit may be undefined or depend on how the limit is taken.

---

### 4.  Summary

- **Small noise does not automatically preserve all expectation values.**  
- If the deterministic flow is *stochastically stable* (unique SRB, hyperbolic, no competing attractors), then  
  \[
       \int g\,d\mu_{\sigma} = \int g\,d\mu_{0} + \mathcal O(\sigma^{2})
  \]
  for smooth \(g\).

- If several invariant sets coexist, small noise produces basin-hopping and the limit is a *mixture*; expectations typically differ.

- For fractal invariant measures the limit works for bounded continuous observables, but can break for rough \(g\).

Hence, **“identical expectations” require uniqueness and robustness of the deterministic physical measure; otherwise they need not coincide, even in the σ→0 limit.**

---

^1 Sketch of the expansion.  Write the adjoint generator  
\(L_{\sigma}^{*}=L_{0}^{*}+\sigma^{2}\Delta\).  
Assume \(L_{0}^{*}\mu_{0}=0\) and \(L_{0}^{*}\) has a spectral gap on Hölder observables.  
Seek \(\mu_{\sigma}=\mu_{0}+\sigma^{2}\nu+o(\sigma^{2})\).  
Plug into \(L_{\sigma}^{*}\mu_{\sigma}=0\) to get \(L_{0}^{*}\nu=-\Delta\mu_{0}\).  
For any \(g\), \(\int g\,d\mu_{\sigma} = \int g\,d\mu_{0} + \sigma^{2}\int g\,d\nu + o(\sigma^{2})\).
